elements.content: The rational design of molecular chains made of 4f ions and substituted 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) radical is presented. The reaction of Ln­(hfac)3·2H2O (hfac– = hexafluoroacetylacetonate) and the 4-cyano-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO-CN) radical affords air- and moisture-stable isostructural molecular chains of the formula [Ln­(hfac)3TEMPO-CN] n for Ln = GdIII and TbIII, whereas zero-dimensional complexes of the formula [Dy­(hfac)3(TEMPO-CN)2]­[Dy­(hfac)3(H2O)2]2 are obtained for Ln = DyIII. To the best of our knowledge, the Gd derivative, Gd-TEMPO-CN, shows one of the strongest antiferromagnetic (AF) couplings for Gd–radical pairs ever reported with J Gd–rad/k B = −21.18 K, 14.72 cm–1 (H = −JS rad S Gd spin Hamiltonian convention). The TbIII derivative, Tb-TEMPO-CN, also shows strong Tb–radical AF coupling, which has been rationalized using the ab initio CASSCF approach (J Tb–rad = −23.02 K, −16.7 cm–1) and confirmed by luminescence measurements. Tb-TEMPO-CN shows remarkable properties for a Tb–radical-based single-molecule magnet (U eff = 69.3 ± 1 K; τ0 = 1.3 × 10–7 s) and two different relaxation processes triggered by interchain magnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: The rational design of molecular chains made of 4f ions and substituted 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) radical is presented. The reaction of Ln(hfac)3⋅2H2O (hfac- = hexafluoroacetylacetonate) and the 4-cyano-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO-CN) radical affords air- and moisture-stable isostructural molecular chains of the formula [Ln(hfac)3TEMPO-CN] n  for Ln = GdIII and TbIII, whereas zero-dimensional complexes of the formula [Dy(hfac)3(TEMPO-CN)2][Dy(hfac)3(H2O)2]2 are obtained for Ln = DyIII. To the best of our knowledge, the Gd derivative, Gd-TEMPO-CN, shows one of the strongest antiferromagnetic (AF) couplings for Gd-radical pairs ever reported with J Gd-rad/k B = -21.18 K, 14.72 cm-1 (H = -JS rad S Gd spin Hamiltonian convention). The TbIII derivative, Tb-TEMPO-CN, also shows strong Tb-radical AF coupling, which has been rationalized using the ab initio CASSCF approach (J Tb-rad = -23.02 K, -16.7 cm-1) and confirmed by luminescence measurements. Tb-TEMPO-CN shows remarkable properties for a Tb-radical-based single-molecule magnet (U eff = 69.3 ± 1 K; τ0 = 1.3 × 10-7 s) and two different relaxation processes triggered by interchain magnetic coupling.

elements.content: Molecular chains of lanthanide ions and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO)-based radicals have been synthesized and show among the strongest reported LnIII−radical magnetic couplings (Ln = Gd, Tb). This is associated with an efficient single-molecule-magnet behavior for the Tb derivative that has been rationalized via ab initio calculations and luminescence measurements.
elements.clean_text: Molecular chains of lanthanide ions and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO)-based radicals have been synthesized and show among the strongest reported LnIII-radical magnetic couplings (Ln = Gd, Tb). This is associated with an efficient single-molecule-magnet behavior for the Tb derivative that has been rationalized via ab initio calculations and luminescence measurements.

elements.content: Organic radicals are among the most efficient building blocks for the design of molecular magnetic materials. They provide strong magnetic coupling with metallic ions and, in particular, they are very well suited to bind 4f ions, whose shielded magnetic orbitals are usually a drawback for their use in extended magnetically coupled structures. Accordingly, a large number of 4f magnetic compounds based on organic radicals, including single-molecule magnets (SMMs) or single-chain magnets (SCMs), have been reported. Recently, astonishing examples of giant coercivity and strong exchange coupling on 4f–radical molecules have been reported.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Organic radicals are among the most efficient building blocks for the design of molecular magnetic materials. They provide strong magnetic coupling with metallic ions and, in particular, they are very well suited to bind 4f ions, whose shielded magnetic orbitals are usually a drawback for their use in extended magnetically coupled structures. Accordingly, a large number of 4f magnetic compounds based on organic radicals, including single-molecule magnets (SMMs) or single-chain magnets (SCMs), have been reported. Recently, astonishing examples of giant coercivity and strong exchange coupling on 4f-radical molecules have been reported.

elements.content: TEMPO-based radicals (TEMPO = 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl) can be considered as a subclass of nitroxide-based radicals. They show remarkable solid-state magnetic properties with long-range magnetic ordering observable at low temperatures, which recalls the first observation of purely organic ferromagnet on p-nitrophenyl nitronyl nitroxide in the early 1990s. Additionally, most of them are temperature-, air-, and moisture-stable, which is a considerable advantage in the search for advanced magnetic devices. Despite these results, TEMPO radicals have received considerably less attention than other radicals to build coordination complexes.
elements.clean_text: TEMPO-based radicals (TEMPO = 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl) can be considered as a subclass of nitroxide-based radicals. They show remarkable solid-state magnetic properties with long-range magnetic ordering observable at low temperatures, which recalls the first observation of purely organic ferromagnet on p-nitrophenyl nitronyl nitroxide in the early 1990s. Additionally, most of them are temperature-, air-, and moisture-stable, which is a considerable advantage in the search for advanced magnetic devices. Despite these results, TEMPO radicals have received considerably less attention than other radicals to build coordination complexes.

elements.content: Indeed, in the search of complexes showing strong Gd–radical magnetic interactions, nitroxide radicals other than TEMPO have been preferred with a record exchange coupling J = −17.4 K (H = −JS Gd S rad convention) observed on Gd-6bpyNO (6bpyNO = 2,2-bipyridine-6-yl tert-butyl nitroxide). It has been demonstrated that a magnetic field as high as 52 T is necessary to decouple the Gd–radical pair, making Gd-6bpyNO the highest antiferromagnetically coupled molecule from gadolinium nitroxide compounds. A small chemical variation on the radical ligand afforded Gd-PhNO (PhNO = tert-butyl phenyl nitroxide), for which a record interaction, ferromagnetic in this case (J = +9 K), has been observed. SMM properties have also been targeted, and 4f nitroxide complexes with interesting magnetic slow relaxation of the TbIII derivative have been reported, highlighting the fact that strong Tb–radical magnetic coupling is able to induce efficient SMM properties even on systems where TbIII ions (oblate by nature) are in a quite distorted environment.

It has been demonstrated that a magnetic field as high as 52 T is necessary to decouple the Gd-radical pair, making Gd-6bpyNO the highest antiferromagnetically coupled molecule from gadolinium nitroxide compounds. A small chemical variation on the radical ligand afforded Gd-PhNO (PhNO = tert-butyl phenyl nitroxide), for which a record interaction, ferromagnetic in this case (J = +9 K), has been observed. SMM properties have also been targeted, and 4f nitroxide complexes with interesting magnetic slow relaxation of the TbIII derivative have been reported, highlighting the fact that strong Tb-radical magnetic coupling is able to induce efficient SMM properties even on systems where TbIII ions (oblate by nature) are in a quite distorted environment.

elements.content: Such little attention dedicated to the TEMPO-based radical is somewhat surprising: first, because its similarity with the above-mentioned record-breaking nitroxides should be appealing to build strongly magnetically coupled molecules, and, second, because the spin localization on the NO group of the TEMPO is larger than the one on nitronyl nitroxides, that have been extensively used to build hybrid organic–inorganic magnetic materials. Coordination of TEMPO radicals on paramagnetic ions might thus lead to molecular edifices with relevant magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: Such little attention dedicated to the TEMPO-based radical is somewhat surprising: first, because its similarity with the above-mentioned record-breaking nitroxides should be appealing to build strongly magnetically coupled molecules, and, second, because the spin localization on the NO group of the TEMPO is larger than the one on nitronyl nitroxides, that have been extensively used to build hybrid organic-inorganic magnetic materials. Coordination of TEMPO radicals on paramagnetic ions might thus lead to molecular edifices with relevant magnetic properties.

elements.content: Indeed, magnetic chains based on 3d ions and 4-subsituted TEMPO radicals have been reported, and some of them show significant coupling between the 3d ion and the nitroxide radical. Similarly, a beautiful example of 2p3d4f complexes has been reported, with 4-azido-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (N3TEMPO) providing various complex topologies and magnetic behaviors.

Similarly, a beautiful example of 2p3d4f complexes has been reported, with 4-azido-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (N3TEMPO) providing various complex topologies and magnetic behaviors.

elements.content: The first report of purely 4f ion coordination on TEMPO radicals was made in 2014 using the genuine TEMPO radical. The TEMPO–Ln-TEMPO complex showed strong antiferromagnetic (AF) superexchange across diamagnetic LaIII and YIII ions (−7.45 and −24.9 K, respectively), with the GdIII derivative presenting both ferromagnetic (+4 K) and AF (−6.45 K) interaction. Interestingly, the ErIII derivative (an ion much less used in molecular magnetism than DyIII and TbIII) shows SMM behavior, which has been rationalized via magnetoluminescent correlations. However, the study of a monobounded Gd-TEMPO complex showed significantly poorer magnetic behavior, highlighting the versatility of the magnetic coupling sign and strength upon coordination.

The TEMPO-Ln-TEMPO complex showed strong antiferromagnetic (AF) superexchange across diamagnetic LaIII and YIII ions (-7.45 and -24.9 K, respectively), with the GdIII derivative presenting both ferromagnetic (+4 K) and AF (-6.45 K) interaction. Interestingly, the ErIII derivative (an ion much less used in molecular magnetism than DyIII and TbIII) shows SMM behavior, which has been rationalized via magnetoluminescent correlations. However, the study of a monobounded Gd-TEMPO complex showed significantly poorer magnetic behavior, highlighting the versatility of the magnetic coupling sign and strength upon coordination.

elements.content: The TEMPO radical can be substituted to provide a nice example of binuclear compounds showing strong 4f–radical magnetic coupling but also SMM behavior for the DyIII and TbIII derivatives. This opens the way to extended TEMPO-based structures by appropriate substitution of the para position of the TEMPO radical.
elements.clean_text: The TEMPO radical can be substituted to provide a nice example of binuclear compounds showing strong 4f-radical magnetic coupling but also SMM behavior for the DyIII and TbIII derivatives. This opens the way to extended TEMPO-based structures by appropriate substitution of the para position of the TEMPO radical.

elements.content: In this work, we have used the 4-cyano-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO-CN) radical (), which is able to bind and magnetically couple a Ln ion via its NO group but also to give rise to an extended magnetic network via its CN coordinating group. The Gd, Tb, and Dy derivatives (namely, Gd-TEMPO-CN, Tb-TEMPO-CN, and Dy-TEMPO-CN) are presented. The targeted molecular chain was obtained for the GdIII and TbIII derivatives with record AF coupling for the former and strong SMM behavior for the latter.

The Gd, Tb, and Dy derivatives (namely, Gd-TEMPO-CN, Tb-TEMPO-CN, and Dy-TEMPO-CN) are presented. The targeted molecular chain was obtained for the GdIII and TbIII derivatives with record AF coupling for the former and strong SMM behavior for the latter.

elements.content:
All starting reagents were purchased from TCI chemicals and used without further purification.

Synthesis

Ln­(hfac)3·2H2O precursors were obtained via reported procedures (hfac– = hexafluoroacetylacetonate). For Dy-TEMPO-CN, 0.1 mmol of Dy­(hfac)3·2H2O was dissolved in 15 mM n-heptane at 70 °C and added to 4 mL of a CHCl3 solution containing 0.1 mmol of TEMPO-CN. The solution was stirred and filtered, and pale-yellow prismatic crystals were obtained after several days. For Tb-TEMPO-CN and Gd-TEMPO-CN, a similar procedure was used and afforded pale-yellow needlelike crystals. Elem anal. Calcd for C65H51F54N4O24Dy3: C, 27,97; H, 1.84; O, 13.76. elements.content: Powder diffractograms were obtained using a Panalytical X-Pert Pro diffractometer equipped with an X’celerator detector. The recording conditions were 45 kV and 45 mA with Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) in θ–θ mode. Simulated patterns from the X-ray crystal structure were obtained with Mercury 3.0 from CCDC.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder diffractograms were obtained using a Panalytical X-Pert Pro diffractometer equipped with an X'celerator detector. The recording conditions were 45 kV and 45 mA with Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) in θ-θ mode. Simulated patterns from the X-ray crystal structure were obtained with Mercury 3.0 from CCDC.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were performed on hand-selected single crystals crunched into powders and embedded in Teflon pellets in order to avoid microcrystallite orientation under a magnetic field. The magnetometer was a Quantum Design MPMS equipped with a low-temperature 3He probe for low-temperature measurements (0.5 K < T < 2 K). All measurements were corrected from the contribution of the sample holder and from the diamagnetic contribution, as calculated with Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Magnetic measurements were performed on hand-selected single crystals crunched into powders and embedded in Teflon pellets in order to avoid microcrystallite orientation under a magnetic field. The magnetometer was a Quantum Design MPMS equipped with a low-temperature 3He probe for low-temperature measurements (0.5 K < T < 2 K). All measurements were corrected from the contribution of the sample holder and from the diamagnetic contribution, as calculated with Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Solid-state emission and excitation spectra were measured on a Horiba JobinYvon Fluorolog III fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a 450 W Xe lamp and a UV–vis photomultiplier (Hamamatsu R928; sensitivity 190–860 nm). Quantum yield measurements were performed using a JobinYvon integrating sphere [Φ = (E c – E a)/(L a – L c), with E c being the integrated emission spectrum of the sample, E a the integrated “blank” emission spectrum, L a the “blank” absorption, and L c the sample absorption at the excitation wavelength]. The emission/excitation spectra and quantum yield recordings were realized on powder samples introduced in cylindrical quartz cells of 0.7 cm diameter and 2.4 cm height, which were placed directly inside the integrating sphere. For the TbIII compound, single crystals were selected and mounted directly onto Cu plates using conductive Ag glue and cooled in an optical cryostat capable of reaching temperatures down to 77 K through a continuous nitrogen-liquid flow and a nitrogen atmosphere inside the sample chamber (Oxford Instruments OptistatCF). Luminescence decays were also measured using this apparatus with a Xe flash lamp (phosphorescence mode). The lifetimes and quantum yields are averages of two independent determinations. Appropriate filters were used to remove the residual excitation laser light, the Rayleigh scattered light, and associated harmonics from the spectra. All spectra were corrected for the instrumental response function.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Measurements

Solid-state emission and excitation spectra were measured on a Horiba JobinYvon Fluorolog III fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a 450 W Xe lamp and a UV-vis photomultiplier (Hamamatsu R928; sensitivity 190-860 nm). Quantum yield measurements were performed using a JobinYvon integrating sphere [Φ = (E c - E a)/(L a - L c), with E c being the integrated emission spectrum of the sample, E a the integrated "blank" emission spectrum, L a the "blank" absorption, and L c the sample absorption at the excitation wavelength]. The emission/excitation spectra and quantum yield recordings were realized on powder samples introduced in cylindrical quartz cells of 0.7 cm diameter and 2.4 cm height, which were placed directly inside the integrating sphere. For the TbIII compound, single crystals were selected and mounted directly onto Cu plates using conductive Ag glue and cooled in an optical cryostat capable of reaching temperatures down to 77 K through a continuous nitrogen-liquid flow and a nitrogen atmosphere inside the sample chamber (Oxford Instruments OptistatCF). Luminescence decays were also measured using this apparatus with a Xe flash lamp (phosphorescence mode). The lifetimes and quantum yields are averages of two independent determinations. Appropriate filters were used to remove the residual excitation laser light, the Rayleigh scattered light, and associated harmonics from the spectra. All spectra were corrected for the instrumental response function.

elements.content: Crystals were mounted on a Bruker AXS diffractometer (APEXII), and the crystal structures were collected at 150 K with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed with Denzo and Scalepack, the crystal structures were solved by SIR97 and refined by SHELX97 via the WINGX interface. H atoms were located at ideal positions. The SQUEEZE procedure was used to remove disordered solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Crystals were mounted on a Bruker AXS diffractometer (APEXII), and the crystal structures were collected at 150 K with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed with Denzo and Scalepack, the crystal structures were solved by SIR97  and refined by SHELX97  via the WINGX  interface. H atoms were located at ideal positions. The SQUEEZE procedure was used to remove disordered solvent molecules.

elements.content: CASSCF and SA-CASSCF/RASSI-SO calculations were carried out on the monomeric model complex of Tb-TEMPO-CN (see the section). The atomic positions of the molecule were extracted from the X-ray crystal structures, and no geometry optimization was performed. All calculations were performed with the MOLCAS quantum chemistry package (version 8.0).
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

CASSCF and SA-CASSCF/RASSI-SO calculations were carried out on the monomeric model complex of Tb-TEMPO-CN (see the  section). The atomic positions of the molecule were extracted from the X-ray crystal structures, and no geometry optimization was performed. All calculations were performed with the MOLCAS quantum chemistry package (version 8.0).

elements.content: First, in order to compute the isotropic magnetic coupling between the TbIII ion and the radical ligand, CASSCF calculations were carried out without considering spin–orbit effects. The active space consisted of the seven 4f orbitals of the TbIII ion plus the singly occupied antibonding π* orbital of the TEMPO-CN ligand: nine electrons in eight orbitals, CAS­(9,8). Calculations were done on both the ferromagnetic and AF states obtained from the interaction of the unpaired electron of the TEMPO-CN radical and the unpaired electrons of the Ln ion. Thus, the lowest octuplet and sextuplet were calculated. The value of the exchange coupling constant was computed within the Heisenberg model.
elements.clean_text: First, in order to compute the isotropic magnetic coupling between the TbIII ion and the radical ligand, CASSCF calculations were carried out without considering spin-orbit effects. The active space consisted of the seven 4f orbitals of the TbIII ion plus the singly occupied antibonding π* orbital of the TEMPO-CN ligand: nine electrons in eight orbitals, CAS(9,8). Calculations were done on both the ferromagnetic and AF states obtained from the interaction of the unpaired electron of the TEMPO-CN radical and the unpaired electrons of the Ln ion. Thus, the lowest octuplet and sextuplet were calculated. The value of the exchange coupling constant was computed within the Heisenberg model.

elements.content: Second, the local electronic and magnetic properties on the Tb center were computed at the SA-CASSCF/RASSI-SO level by doping the TEMPO-CN radical with an extra electron to obtain a diamagnetic analogue. The active space only consists in eight electrons in seven 4f orbitals, i.e., CAS­(8,7). In this approach, spin–orbit coupling was added within the restricted-active-space state-interaction (RASSI-SO) method, which uses the CASSCF spin-free wave functions as basis states. State-averaged CASSCF calculations were performed for the 7 septuplets and 140 quintuplets of the TbIII ion. All states were included in the RASSI-SO calculation. The resulting wave functions and energies were used to compute the magnetic properties and g tensors of the lowest states from the energy spectrum by using the pseudospin S = 1/2 formalism in the SINGLE-ANISO routine. This is possible because, despite being a non-Kramers ion, quasi-degenerate ground and first-excited spin–orbit states are found for TbIII (vide infra, Table S8). Simulations of the χM T data were done with the POLY_ANISO program using the computed single-ion anisotropy. The exchange coupling interaction between the Tb center and the coordinated isotropic S = 1/2 radical was computed within the Lines model. Cholesky decomposition of the bielectronic integrals was employed to save disk space and speed up the calculations. All atoms were described by ANO-RCC basis sets. The following contractions were used: [8s7p4d3f2g1h] for the Tb atom, [4s3p2d] for the O and N atoms, [3s2p] for C and F atoms, and [2s] for the H atoms.

elements.content: The reaction of Dy­(hfac)3·2H2O and the TEMPO-CN radical affords compound Dy-TEMPO-CN, which crystallizes in the C2/c (No. 15) space group. The main crystallographic data are reported in . The crystal structure can be described as one Dy­(hfac)3 entity (that involves the Dy1 atom) coordinated by two different TEMPO-CN ligands through their NO groups that host the radical (). Such a coordination mode is likely to provide strong radical–Dy coupling. This molecule is surrounded by two uncoordinated Dy­(hfac)3·2H2O molecules (that involve Dy2 atoms) that interact through hydrogen bonds via one of their water molecules and the CN groups of the TEMPO-CN radicals. The second water molecule is involved in hydrogen bonding with another Dy­(hfac)3·2H2O molecule that further hydrogen bonds another TEMPO-CN ligand ( and S1). Overall, the compounds can be considered as planes where radical–Dy–radical molecules alternate with chains of Dy­(hfac)3·2H2O molecules. In these molecules, Dy2–Ohfac– distances are in the range 2.302(4)–2.414(3) Å, while for Dy1–Ohfac– , the range is 2.336(3)–2.345(4) Å. The O4–Dy1–O4 angle is 141.14°, and the two radicals coordinated to Dy1 are almost parallel.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description

The reaction of Dy(hfac)3⋅2H2O and the TEMPO-CN radical affords compound Dy-TEMPO-CN, which crystallizes in the C2/c (No. 15) space group. The main crystallographic data are reported in . The crystal structure can be described as one Dy(hfac)3 entity (that involves the Dy1 atom) coordinated by two different TEMPO-CN ligands through their NO groups that host the radical (). Such a coordination mode is likely to provide strong radical-Dy coupling. This molecule is surrounded by two uncoordinated Dy(hfac)3⋅2H2O molecules (that involve Dy2 atoms) that interact through hydrogen bonds via one of their water molecules and the CN groups of the TEMPO-CN radicals. The second water molecule is involved in hydrogen bonding with another Dy(hfac)3⋅2H2O molecule that further hydrogen bonds another TEMPO-CN ligand ( and S1). Overall, the compounds can be considered as planes where radical-Dy-radical molecules alternate with chains of Dy(hfac)3⋅2H2O molecules. In these molecules, Dy2-Ohfac-  distances are in the range 2.302(4)-2.414(3) Å, while for Dy1-Ohfac- , the range is 2.336(3)-2.345(4) Å. The O4-Dy1-O4 angle is 141.14°, and the two radicals coordinated to Dy1 are almost parallel.

elements.content: Numerous highly disordered solvent molecules have been found between the planes and removed in the refinement process (SQUEEZE procedure). Dy1 is coordinated by six O atoms from three hfac– anions and two nitroxide O atoms from two radicals. Dy2 is coordinated by six O atoms from three hfac– anions and two O atoms from two water molecules. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1. The geometry of the Dy1 coordination polyhedron is a triangular dodecahedron [D 2d ; continuous shape measurement (CSM) factor = 0.431; Table S2], whereas Dy2 can be described either by a distorted square antiprism (D 4d ; CSM = 0.937) or a triangular dodecahedron (D 2d ; CSM = 0.911). The smallest Dy–Dy distance is found between uncoordinated Dy­(hfac)3 molecules and the closest radical–Dy–radical molecule and is 6.06 Å.

elements.content: The reaction of Tb­(hfac)3·2H2O and the TEMPO-CN radical (compound Tb-TEMPO-CN) affords single crystals suitable of single-crystal X-ray diffraction. No single crystals have been obtained for its GdIII analogue, Gd-TEMPO-CN but isostructurality is evidenced by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S2). Compound Tb-TEMPO-CN crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group (No. 2). The main crystallographic data are reported in . The asymmetric unit is made of one Tb­(hfac)3 entity bound to one TEMPO-CN molecule through its NO group from one side and another TEMPO-CN molecule through its CN group from the other side ( and ). The NTEMPO–Tb–OTEMPO angle is 146.29°, and the torsion angle of the CN and NO groups of the same TEMPO-CN is 170.40°. Overall, a molecular chain is formed along the b axis. The Tb ion is in a O7N1 environment made of six O atoms from three hfac– ancillary ligands, one O atom from a NO group of a TEMPO-CN, and one N atom from a CN group of another TEMPO-CN. The coordination environment is a distorted square antiprism (D 4d ; CSM = 0.929; Table S2).

elements.content: The Tb–Ohfac bond lengths are in the 2.330(3)–2.387(3) Å range, while the Tb–OTEMPO bond length is 2.2891(2) Å, slightly shorter than that of Tb–Ohfac. The Tb–N bond lengths are 2.540(3) Å. Additional bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S3. The shortest intrachain Tb–Tb distance is 11.12(6) Å, ruling out strong in-chain metal–metal and radical–radical interactions. The shortest interchain Tb–Tb distances are 8.41(5) Å, suggesting possible dipole–dipole interactions between the chains.

elements.content: In order to quantify the magnetic coupling abilities of the TEMPO-CN radical with 4f ions, we have first investigated the GdIII derivative [Gd­(hfac)3TEMPO-CN)] n (Gd-TEMPO-CN), which is isostructural to Tb-TEMPO-CN. The room temperature χM T value is 8.38 cm3 K mol–1 (), close to the theoretical value expected for an uncoupled GdIII ion (8F7/2, g = 2, χM T = 7.88 cm3 K mol–1) plus one radical spin (χM T = 0.375 cm3 K mol–1). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases progressively to reach a plateau around 15 K for χM T = 6.06 cm3 K mol–1. This is a clear signature of a system that reaches S total = 3. A final drop until 5.5 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K is attributed to weak intermolecular (interchain) AF couplings. This behavior has been fitted considering the spin Hamiltonian H = −JS rad S Gd with the introduction of a mean-field zJ′ intermolecular interaction (). χ M T = 4 N A g 2 μ B 2 k B ⁡ 7 + 15 ⁡ exp ( 4 J Gd − rad / k B T ) 7 + 9 ⁡ exp ( 4 J Gd − rad / k B T ) ⁡ T T − z J ′
elements.clean_text:
Static Magnetic Properties

In order to quantify the magnetic coupling abilities of the TEMPO-CN radical with 4f ions, we have first investigated the GdIII derivative [Gd(hfac)3TEMPO-CN)] n  (Gd-TEMPO-CN), which is isostructural to Tb-TEMPO-CN. The room temperature χM T value is 8.38 cm3 K mol-1 (), close to the theoretical value expected for an uncoupled GdIII ion (8F7/2, g = 2, χM T = 7.88 cm3 K mol-1) plus one radical spin (χM T = 0.375 cm3 K mol-1). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases progressively to reach a plateau around 15 K for χM T = 6.06 cm3 K mol-1. This is a clear signature of a system that reaches S total = 3. A final drop until 5.5 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K is attributed to weak intermolecular (interchain) AF couplings. This behavior has been fitted considering the spin Hamiltonian H = -JS rad S Gd with the introduction of a mean-field zJ' intermolecular interaction (). 1      χ   M   T =   4   N   A     g   2       μ   B     2       k   B     ⁡   7 + 15 ⁡ exp  ( 4   J   Gd - rad   /   k   B   T )    7 + 9 ⁡ exp  ( 4   J   Gd - rad   /   k   B   T )    ⁡   T   T - z J '

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the χM T product for Gd-TEMPO-CN with the best fit obtained with eq (J Gd–rad/k B = −21.18 ± 0.24 K (−14.72 cm–1), g = 2.01 ± 0.001, and zJ′ = −0.029 ± 0.001). The inset shows the field variation of magnetization at 2 K with simulation of the Brillouin function for S total = 3.
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of the χM T product for Gd-TEMPO-CN with the best fit obtained with eq   (J Gd-rad/k B = -21.18 ± 0.24 K (-14.72 cm-1), g = 2.01 ± 0.001, and zJ' = -0.029 ± 0.001). The inset shows the field variation of magnetization at 2 K with simulation of the Brillouin function for S total = 3.

elements.content: The best fit is obtained for J Gd–rad/k B = −21.18 ± 0.24 K (−14.72 cm–1), g = 2.01 ± 0.001, zJ′ = −0.029 ± 0.001 K, and R 2 = 0.99804. To the best of our knowledge, this value is among the highest Gd–radical couplings ever reported and is overcome only by two reports on N2 3– radical-bridged dimers. Indeed, coupling constants on gadolinium nitronyl nitroxide radicals or gadolinium nitroxide radicals (see and ) are usually below 12 K. The additional AF interchain interaction zJ′ is found to be rather weak, which is a common observation of dipolar interchain coupling in 4f–radical-based chains. The field dependence of magnetization at 2 K is depicted in the inset of , and magnetization saturates at 6.06 μB, close to the value expected for S total = 3 and g = 2, which confirms the strong AF coupling. Indeed, the curve is almost superimposable with a simulation using the Brillouin function for S = 3 at 2 K.

To the best of our knowledge, this value is among the highest Gd-radical couplings ever reported and is overcome only by two reports on N2 3- radical-bridged dimers. Indeed, coupling constants on gadolinium nitronyl nitroxide radicals or gadolinium nitroxide radicals (see  and ) are usually below 12 K. Abbreviations: 2PyNO = tert-butyl 2-pyridyl nitroxide, DTBN = di-tert-butylnitroxide, 6bpyNO = 2,2-bipyridine-6-yl tert-butyl nitroxide, phNO = tert-butyl phenyl nitroxide, 3tolNO = N-tert-butyl-N-(3-tolyl)­hydroxylamine, 4tbNO = N-tert-butyl-N-(4-tert-butylphenyl)­hydroxylamine, TMIO = 1,1,3,3-tetramethylisoindolin-2-oxyl, dppn = (diphenylphosphinyl)­amino, IPhIN = 1-iodo-3,5-bis­(4′,4′,5′,5′-tetramethyl-4′,5′-dihydro-1H-imidazole-1′-oxyl)­benzene), and TEMPO = 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl.

On a theoretical point of view, density functional theory (DFT) approaches demonstrated that the magnetic coupling mechanism is based on the overlap between the GdIII magnetic orbitals and π* orbitals of the radical, the latter being able to gain occupation from the 5d/6s/6p GdIII empty orbitals via a charge-transfer mechanism. In this framework, the influence of the Gd–O bond distance and/or on the Gd–X–Y–Csp2 dihedral angles (where X–Y stands for O–N, O–C, N–C, or N–N atoms) has been considered. Actually, these two parameters have been used empirically to establish magnetostructural correlations on gadolinium nitroxide radical derivatives. However, aforementioned DFT studies conclude that if each of these parameters is found to be relevant, no clear trend considering their mixed contribution over a large series of compounds has been found. We obtained a similar conclusion here on gadolinium nitroxide compounds reported in .

In this framework, the influence of the Gd-O bond distance and/or on the Gd-X-Y-Csp2  dihedral angles (where X-Y stands for O-N, O-C, N-C, or N-N atoms) has been considered. Actually, these two parameters have been used empirically to establish magnetostructural correlations on gadolinium nitroxide radical derivatives. However, aforementioned DFT studies conclude that if each of these parameters is found to be relevant, no clear trend considering their mixed contribution over a large series of compounds has been found. We obtained a similar conclusion here on gadolinium nitroxide compounds reported in .

elements.content: Derivatives likely to give rise to SMM behavior (Dy-TEMPO-CN and Tb-TEMPO-CN) have also been investigated by static magnetic measurements carried out on polycrystalline powders. On Dy-TEMPO-CN, the room temperature χM T value is 43.59 cm3 K mol–1, in agreement with the expected value of 43.26 cm3 K mol–1 for three isolated DyIII ions (6H15/2, g = 4/3, and χM T 300 K = 14.17 cm3 K mol–1) plus two radical spins (χM T 300 K = 0.75 cm3 K mol–1) (Figure S3). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases to reach 26.03 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. This behavior is interplay between the depopulation of the Stark sublevels of each of the DyIII ions (Dy1 and Dy2) and possible Dy2–Dy2 and radical–Dy1 interactions. These numerous pathways for magnetic interactions make evaluation of the radical–Dy1 interaction hardly reliable.
elements.clean_text: Derivatives likely to give rise to SMM behavior (Dy-TEMPO-CN and Tb-TEMPO-CN) have also been investigated by static magnetic measurements carried out on polycrystalline powders. On Dy-TEMPO-CN, the room temperature χM T value is 43.59 cm3 K mol-1, in agreement with the expected value of 43.26 cm3 K mol-1 for three isolated DyIII ions (6H15/2, g = 4/3, and χM T 300 K = 14.17 cm3 K mol-1) plus two radical spins (χM T 300 K = 0.75 cm3 K mol-1) (Figure S3). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases to reach 26.03 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K. This behavior is interplay between the depopulation of the Stark sublevels of each of the DyIII ions (Dy1 and Dy2) and possible Dy2-Dy2 and radical-Dy1 interactions. These numerous pathways for magnetic interactions make evaluation of the radical-Dy1 interaction hardly reliable.

elements.content: On Tb-TEMPO-CN, the room temperature χM T value is 11.98 cm3 K mol–1, close to the expected value of 12.20 cm3 K mol–1 for an uncoupled TbIII ion (7F6, g = 3/2, and χM T 300 K = 11.82 cm3 K mol–1) plus one radical spin (χM T 300 K = 0.375 cm3 K mol–1). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases progressively to reach a plateau clearly visible at 5 K followed by a decrease toward 7.29 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. A slight kink around 6 K is clearly visible (). This allows us to suspect a dual contribution of the depopulation of Stark sublevels of the TbIII ion and an AF coupling in the Tb–radical pair. At low temperature (T < 5 K), the additional contribution of AF interchain interactions is also suspected.

elements.content: To gain insight into the magnetic properties of Tb-TEMPO-CN, a two-step computational protocol based on CASSCF calculations was followed (see ). This approach was used previously by Totti and co-workers on another series of Ln–radical complexes. On the one hand, SA-CASSCF/RASSI-SO calculations on the model complex (see ) with an extra electron on the TEMPO-CN radical have been performed. The computed energies of the low-lying electronic states are given in and evidence both the quasi-degenerate ground spin–orbit state (0.17 cm–1) and an overall splitting of the 7F6 level of 501 cm–1, in agreement with the luminescence data (see below). A strong local easy axis has been calculated for Tb (g x = 0.000; g y = 0.000; g z = 17.74). As shown in , the easy axis is oriented almost parallel to the square faces of the coordination polyhedron. On the other hand, CAS­(9,8)­SCF calculations with no spin–orbit contribution were carried out on the lowest octuplet and sextuplet states. Within the Heisenberg model, an AF J Tb–rad coupling of −23.02 K (−16.7 cm–1) was computed. On the basis of these calculations, the χM T versus T curve was simulated with great agreement with the experimental data ( and S4). No interchain interactions were considered in the simulations, explaining that the drop at low temperature is not reproduced.
elements.clean_text:
Ab Initio Calculations

To gain insight into the magnetic properties of Tb-TEMPO-CN, a two-step computational protocol based on CASSCF calculations was followed (see ). This approach was used previously by Totti and co-workers on another series of Ln-radical complexes. On the one hand, SA-CASSCF/RASSI-SO calculations on the model complex (see ) with an extra electron on the TEMPO-CN radical have been performed. The computed energies of the low-lying electronic states are given in  and evidence both the quasi-degenerate ground spin-orbit state (0.17 cm-1) and an overall splitting of the 7F6 level of 501 cm-1, in agreement with the luminescence data (see below). A strong local easy axis has been calculated for Tb (g  x  = 0.000; g  y  = 0.000; g  z  = 17.74). As shown in , the easy axis is oriented almost parallel to the square faces of the coordination polyhedron. On the other hand, CAS(9,8)SCF calculations with no spin-orbit contribution were carried out on the lowest octuplet and sextuplet states. Within the Heisenberg model, an AF J Tb-rad coupling of -23.02 K (-16.7 cm-1) was computed. On the basis of these calculations, the χM T versus T curve was simulated with great agreement with the experimental data ( and S4). No interchain interactions were considered in the simulations, explaining that the drop at low temperature is not reproduced.

elements.content: Ln ions can present luminescence in the visible region upon UV irradiation. Some of us demonstrated that the detailed investigation of the solid-state luminescent spectrum of Ln-based SMMs is able to provide information on the energy scheme responsible for their magnetic behavior. This has also been generalized for near-IR-emissive Ln-SMM. Since then, magnetoluminescent correlations flourished.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetoluminescent Correlations

Ln ions can present luminescence in the visible region upon UV irradiation. Some of us demonstrated that the detailed investigation of the solid-state luminescent spectrum of Ln-based SMMs is able to provide information on the energy scheme responsible for their magnetic behavior. This has also been generalized for near-IR-emissive Ln-SMM. Since then, magnetoluminescent correlations flourished.

elements.content: Low-temperature (77 K) solid-state luminescence spectra measured on a single crystal of Tb-TEMPO-CN are provided in . The excitation spectrum highlights a broad band below 330 nm that is attributed to π*­(hfac) → π­(hfac) transitions. Hence, with λexc = 325 nm, the characteristic TbIII emission from 5D4 → 7F J radiative transitions is observed. Detailed measurement of the 5D4 → 7F6 transition is provided in (see also Figures S5 and S6). The overall splitting of the 7F6 level is estimated to be 510 cm–1, which well matches with the ab initio calculations (501 cm–1). Further deconvolution and analysis of this emission peak has not been possible because of the low emissive properties of Tb-TEMPO-CN. Accordingly, no reliable quantum yield and lifetime measurement could be extracted. No emission has been observed on Dy-TEMPO-CN. For information, we provide the luminescence measurements of Eu-TEMPO-CN in Figure S7. A quantum yield of φLig–Eu = 1.1(1)% associated with a lifetime of τ = 0.43(1) ms is observed.

elements.content:
Dynamic magnetic measurements have been performed on Dy-TEMPO-CN and Tb-TEMPO-CN.

On the Dy derivative, no zero-field χM″ signal has been observed. An optimum direct-current (dc) field of H dc = 2400 Oe was necessary to remove fast-relaxing processes in the sample (Figure S8). Two sets of peaks can be observed, in line with the presence of two different Dy ions in the crystal structure ( and S9). Extraction of the relaxation times (τ) in an Arrhenius plot (ln τ vs T –1) affords two linear regimes that can be fitted tentatively considering an Orbach relaxation process [τ = τ0 exp­(U eff/k B T), with τ0 the characteristic relaxation time and U eff the effective energy barrier for spin reversal]. Given the crossover between the two regimes, it has been impossible to consider additional relaxation processes (Raman, etc.) without reasonable errors. Fittings provide U eff = 11.3 ± 0.7 K with τ0 = 1.04 × 10–5 s for the low-temperature regime and U eff = 8.9 ± 0.5 K with τ0 = 1.10 × 10–5 s for the high-temperature regime ( and Table S4). The two relaxation regimes are also clearly evidenced on Cole–Cole plots ( and Table S5). These plots allow estimation of the distribution of relaxation times in the sample with 0 < α < 1 for a single (α = 0) or an infinite distribution of the relaxation times (α = 1). On Dy-TEMPO-CN, α values are quite high, with 0.48 < α < 0.56 and 0.27 < α < 0.39 for the low- and high-temperature regimes, respectively.

Dynamic Magnetic Properties

Dynamic magnetic measurements have been performed on Dy-TEMPO-CN and Tb-TEMPO-CN.

On the Dy derivative, no zero-field χM" signal has been observed. An optimum direct-current (dc) field of H dc = 2400 Oe was necessary to remove fast-relaxing processes in the sample (Figure S8). Two sets of peaks can be observed, in line with the presence of two different Dy ions in the crystal structure ( and S9). Extraction of the relaxation times (τ) in an Arrhenius plot (ln τ vs T -1) affords two linear regimes that can be fitted tentatively considering an Orbach relaxation process [τ = τ0 exp(U eff/k B T), with τ0 the characteristic relaxation time and U eff the effective energy barrier for spin reversal]. Given the crossover between the two regimes, it has been impossible to consider additional relaxation processes (Raman, etc.) without reasonable errors. Fittings provide U eff = 11.3 ± 0.7 K with τ0 = 1.04 × 10-5 s for the low-temperature regime and U eff = 8.9 ± 0.5 K with τ0 = 1.10 × 10-5 s for the high-temperature regime ( and Table S4). The two relaxation regimes are also clearly evidenced on Cole-Cole plots ( and Table S5). These plots allow estimation of the distribution of relaxation times in the sample with 0 < α < 1 for a single (α = 0) or an infinite distribution of the relaxation times (α = 1). On Dy-TEMPO-CN, α values are quite high, with 0.48 < α < 0.56 and 0.27 < α < 0.39 for the low- and high-temperature regimes, respectively.

elements.content: The Tb derivative (Tb-TEMPO-CN) shows significantly better magnetic slow relaxation than 1. Under an optimum dc field of 2000 Oe (Figure S10), the frequency dependence of alternating-current (ac) signals is observed for temperatures as high as 10 K (). Extraction of the relaxation times (Table S6) affords an Arrhenius plot whose high-temperature regime (8 K < T < 10 K) can be fitted considering an Orbach relaxation process to afford U eff = 69.3 ± 1 K, which is among the highest values for a terbium nitroxide or terbium nitronyl nitroxide compound (see ) associated with τ0 = 1.31 × 10–7 s. These findings confirm that a strong interaction between the TbIII ion and S = 1/2 spin carriers such as radicals or CuII ions leads to remarkable SMM behavior. At lower temperature (T < 6 K), another linear regime is observed (U eff = 20.1 ± 0.2 and τ0 = 1.9 × 10–4 s). It is worth noticing that any attempts to fit the extracted relaxation times (τ) over the whole investigated temperature range failed, even considering combinations of various relaxation processes. The low-temperature regime is then related to a magnetic object that is severely affected by interchain interactions. This is in line with the static magnetic measurement, where a kink at 6 K is observed (). This also recalls the observation made on Gd-TEMPO-CN, where a sizable interchain interaction has been quantified below 6 K (). Last, this is in agreement with our recent study, which demonstrates that small interchain dipolar couplings at relatively long distances have a significant impact on the magnetic relaxation of Ln ions.

Single-chain magnet.

No further flattening of the Arrhenius plot is observed at low temperature, suggesting that the combination of the Tb–radical magnetic coupling and the applied dc field efficiently suppresses quantum tunneling in Tb-TEMPO-CN. This prompted us to perform low-temperature (T = 0.5 K) hysteresis measurement, and a very small opening of the magnetic hysteresis loop is observed around 2000 Oe (Figure S11).

elements.content: In order to confirm these findings, Cole–Cole plots have been fitted ( and Table S7) and two regimes can be observed. At high temperature, low α values (α9 K = 0.005) associated with a relaxing fraction of 1 – χS/χT = 82% [with χS the adiabatic and χT the isotherm susceptibility, and 1 – χS/χT represents the amount of sample that undergoes magnetic slow relaxation] are observed. In the low-temperature regime (T < 6 K), a better relaxing fraction is observed (ca. 90%), but with higher α (α2 K = 0.44). This is in line with the presence of several interchain interactions below 6 K, which broadens the relaxation time distribution.

elements.content: In this study, LnIII ions have been associated with the TEMPO-CN radical with the aim of building molecular magnetic chains. Indeed, the CN group of the radical ligand is able to bind GdIII and TbIII ions to form a one-dimensional molecular edifice in which strong Ln–radical AF interaction is observed. For Gd-TEMPO-CN, the coupling is J Gd–rad = −21.18 K (zJ′ = −0.029 K), the highest Gd–radical coupling ever reported with nitroxide-based radicals. Tb-TEMPO-CN shows a similar behavior, with J Tb–rad = −23.02 K estimated from ab initio calculations. Magnetoluminescent correlations have been undertaken and single-crystal luminescence measurements of the overall splitting of the 7F6 ground state well match with those found via ab initio calculations. Additionally, Tb-TEMPO-CN shows significant SMM behavior for a Ln–radical-based compound with U eff = 69.3 ± 1 K and τ0 = 1.31 × 10–7 s. These findings are extremely promising for the design of new air- and moisture-stable magnetic materials, and TEMPO radicals are proposed as an efficient alternative to the widely used nitronyl nitroxide radicals.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this study, LnIII ions have been associated with the TEMPO-CN radical with the aim of building molecular magnetic chains. Indeed, the CN group of the radical ligand is able to bind GdIII and TbIII ions to form a one-dimensional molecular edifice in which strong Ln-radical AF interaction is observed. For Gd-TEMPO-CN, the coupling is J Gd-rad = -21.18 K (zJ' = -0.029 K), the highest Gd-radical coupling ever reported with nitroxide-based radicals. Tb-TEMPO-CN shows a similar behavior, with J Tb-rad = -23.02 K estimated from ab initio calculations. Magnetoluminescent correlations have been undertaken and single-crystal luminescence measurements of the overall splitting of the 7F6 ground state well match with those found via ab initio calculations. Additionally, Tb-TEMPO-CN shows significant SMM behavior for a Ln-radical-based compound with U eff = 69.3 ± 1 K and τ0 = 1.31 × 10-7 s. These findings are extremely promising for the design of new air- and moisture-stable magnetic materials, and TEMPO radicals are proposed as an efficient alternative to the widely used nitronyl nitroxide radicals.

cln_elements.content:
Derivatives likely to give rise to SMM behavior (Dy-TEMPO-CN and Tb-TEMPO-CN) have also been investigated by static magnetic measurements carried out on polycrystalline powders. On Dy-TEMPO-CN, the room temperature χM T value is 43.59 cm3 K mol–1, in agreement with the expected value of 43.26 cm3 K mol–1 for three isolated DyIII ions (6H15/2, g = 4/3, and χM T 300 K = 14.17 cm3 K mol–1) plus two radical spins (χM T 300 K = 0.75 cm3 K mol–1) (Figure S3). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases to reach 26.03 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. This behavior is interplay between the depopulation of the Stark sublevels of each of the DyIII ions (Dy1 and Dy2) and possible Dy2–Dy2 and radical–Dy1 interactions. These numerous pathways for magnetic interactions make evaluation of the radical–Dy1 interaction hardly reliable.

On Tb-TEMPO-CN, the room temperature χM T value is 11.98 cm3 K mol–1, close to the expected value of 12.20 cm3 K mol–1 for an uncoupled TbIII ion (7F6, g = 3/2, and χM T 300 K = 11.82 cm3 K mol–1) plus one radical spin (χM T 300 K = 0.375 cm3 K mol–1). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases progressively to reach a plateau clearly visible at 5 K followed by a decrease toward 7.29 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. A slight kink around 6 K is clearly visible (). This allows us to suspect a dual contribution of the depopulation of Stark sublevels of the TbIII ion and an AF coupling in the Tb–radical pair. At low temperature (T < 5 K), the additional contribution of AF interchain interactions is also suspected.

Conclusion

In this study, LnIII ions have been associated with the TEMPO-CN radical with the aim of building molecular magnetic chains. Indeed, the CN group of the radical ligand is able to bind GdIII and TbIII ions to form a one-dimensional molecular edifice in which strong Ln–radical AF interaction is observed. For Gd-TEMPO-CN, the coupling is J Gd–rad = −21.18 K (zJ′ = −0.029 K), the highest Gd–radical coupling ever reported with nitroxide-based radicals. Tb-TEMPO-CN shows a similar behavior, with J Tb–rad = −23.02 K estimated from ab initio calculations. Magnetoluminescent correlations have been undertaken and single-crystal luminescence measurements of the overall splitting of the 7F6 ground state well match with those found via ab initio calculations. Additionally, Tb-TEMPO-CN shows significant SMM behavior for a Ln–radical-based compound with U eff = 69.3 ± 1 K and τ0 = 1.31 × 10–7 s. These findings are extremely promising for the design of new air- and moisture-stable magnetic materials, and TEMPO radicals are proposed as an efficient alternative to the widely used nitronyl nitroxide radicals.

These numerous pathways for magnetic interactions make evaluation of the radical-Dy1 interaction hardly reliable.

On Tb-TEMPO-CN, the room temperature χM T value is 11.98 cm3 K mol-1, close to the expected value of 12.20 cm3 K mol-1 for an uncoupled TbIII ion (7F6, g = 3/2, and χM T 300 K = 11.82 cm3 K mol-1) plus one radical spin (χM T 300 K = 0.375 cm3 K mol-1). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases progressively to reach a plateau clearly visible at 5 K followed by a decrease toward 7.29 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. A slight kink around 6 K is clearly visible (). This allows us to suspect a dual contribution of the depopulation of Stark sublevels of the TbIII ion and an AF coupling in the Tb-radical pair. At low temperature (T < 5 K), the additional contribution of AF interchain interactions is also suspected.

Conclusion

In this study, LnIII ions have been associated with the TEMPO-CN radical with the aim of building molecular magnetic chains. Indeed, the CN group of the radical ligand is able to bind GdIII and TbIII ions to form a one-dimensional molecular edifice in which strong Ln-radical AF interaction is observed. For Gd-TEMPO-CN, the coupling is J Gd-rad = -21.18 K (zJ' = -0.029 K), the highest Gd-radical coupling ever reported with nitroxide-based radicals. Tb-TEMPO-CN shows a similar behavior, with J Tb-rad = -23.02 K estimated from ab initio calculations. Magnetoluminescent correlations have been undertaken and single-crystal luminescence measurements of the overall splitting of the 7F6 ground state well match with those found via ab initio calculations. Additionally, Tb-TEMPO-CN shows significant SMM behavior for a Ln-radical-based compound with U eff = 69.3 ± 1 K and τ0 = 1.31 × 10-7 s. These findings are extremely promising for the design of new air- and moisture-stable magnetic materials, and TEMPO radicals are proposed as an efficient alternative to the widely used nitronyl nitroxide radicals.
